title: Pelosi Faces Narrow Margin in House Speaker Vote
sub_head: Lawmakers reconvene with smaller Democratic majority and absences expected because of coronavirus
body:
WASHINGTON—Nancy Pelosi (D., Calif.) is poised to win her fourth term as House speaker on Sunday, but a narrower Democratic majority and uncertainties caused by the coronavirus pandemic will make for little wiggle room.
Mrs. Pelosi has spent time in recent weeks shoring up support among Democrats to be able to carry a majority of those present and voting by name, as every vote will matter for the speakership as Congress convenes for its new session.
Democrats expect to have 222 seats to Republicans’ 211. One race in New York is still in dispute, and a seat in Louisiana will be vacant because Republican Rep.-elect Luke Letlow died on Tuesday from complications of Covid-19. Two other Republican lawmakers are expected to be absent because they have tested positive for Covid-19. It isn’t known if any Democrats will miss the vote.
“My opponent is Covid,” Mrs. Pelosi said on a call last week with Democrats discussing the speakership, according to a person on the call. To the public, she has asserted a confident position, saying last week she definitely expects to have a majority present and that she isn’t worried about getting re-elected.
Rather than assemble at once, House lawmakers will enter the chamber in groups on Sunday to enforce social distancing, which is expected to drag out a generally fast process into one that lasts several hours. First, a roll call will determine who is present. Then, lawmakers will select the speaker of the House. After that, members will take the oath of office in groups.
